rEHNSx-y6.memHandModelNotes: ***Hand Modeling: Species avoids dense wooded tracts (Mitchell 1994) and woodland habitat is generally considered the primary habitat, use Forest interior layer as an avoid mask.  Did not want to use an ecotonal buffer for this species because it may be too restrictive.  If we need to broaden this species range we could buffer from grassy open areas such pasture and grassland into the hardwood forested classes to pick up woodland pixels outside of the coastal plain.  In Arkansas, individuals had large, well-defined home ranges of 21-73 ha (average 50 ha, n = 8), which for individuals remained similar in size and location from year to year (Plummer and Mills 2000, in NatureServe 2006). So applied avoid buffer based on these 50ha home range.  50ha=50K sq m =~ 700m so used -500m**Also, a detailed soils layer would aid in better predicting this species distribution.  Amy Silvano 18Aug05

habitat_description:
The distribution of the eastern hog-nosed snake encompasses areas from southern New England through southern Ontario to Minnesota and south Dakota, southern Texas, the Gulf Coast, and southern Florida (Conant and Collins 1991; Ernst and Ernst 2003).

This species is found in riparian zones, cropland, grassland, old fields, and conifer, hardwood, and mixed woodland. The habitat includes forest edges, fields, fire-managed pinelands, forest-grassland ecotones, river valleys, woodland meadows, barrier islands, and openly wooded upland hills. The habitat of preference is usually characterized by the presence of amphibian prey and loose soils.The eastern hog-nosed snake is described as a terrestrial snake that burrows in or using soil; it crawls over the surface and burrows into soil. It is known to hibernate in burrows or under rocks of talus slopes. Eggs are laid in nests only a few inches below the surface or in decaying wood (Degraaf and Rudis 1983; Platt 1969).
